div.p: From Jaspar Kern
Signatur: 4630, Grossherzogliches Kabinett III, Mecklenburgisches Landeshaptarchiv Schwerin.

To proof.
Allerdurchlauchtigster Grossherzog,
Allergnädigster Grossherzog und Herr!

Der Director des Botanischen Gartens in Melbourne Colony Victoria in Australien, Dr. Ferd. Mueller Sohn des weilend Steuerbeamten Mueller in Rostock ersuchte mich bei meiner Heimkehr ins theure Vaterland, seine nachbezeichneten, beigehenden Werke, als:
1. The Plants indignenous to the Colony of Victoria
2. Fragmenta Phytographiae Australiae Vol IV
3. Fragmenta Phytographiae Australiae XXXI und
4. The Fate of Dr. Leichhardt and a proposed New Search of His Party
mitzunehmen und Euer Königlichen Hoheit allerunterthänigst zu überreichen, mit der devotesten Bitte

Allerhöchst Dieselben wollen geruhen, diese als Beweis tiefster Devotion von demselben huldvoll aufzunehmen und der Ehre einer Einverleibung in die Grossherzolgliche Biblithek theilhaft werden zu lassen.

In welcher Weise der Dr. Frd. Mueller als Mecklenburger des theure Vaterland vertritt und zu dessen Ehre in einem fernen Welttheil wirkt, daran zeugen die Insignien mit welchen die Brust dieses anerkannten Gelehrten dessen photographische Bild ich allerunterthänigst beizulegen wage — bereits d[…] worden.
Mit innigstem Hochgefühl habe ich hierdurch diesen Auftrag meiner werthen Landsmannes frudigst ausgerichtet.

div.p: Jaspar Friedrick Kern
Wismar
den 10ten Novber 1865.
Most illustrious Grand Duke
Most gracious Grand Duke and Lord!

The director of the Botanical Garden in Melbourne, Colony of Victoria in Australia, Dr. Ferd. Mueller, son of the former tax official Mueller in Rostock, asked me on my return to the dear fatherland
Kern, a civil engineer, had been working on railway construction and had attempted to obtain land to establish an educational campus near Castlemaine, Vic.(Mount Alexander mail, 4 Feb 1864, p. 3). to take with me his works indicated to hand as:
1. The Plants indigenous to the Colony of Victoria
2. Fragmenta Phytographiae Australiae Vol IV
3. Fragmenta Phytographiae Australiae XXXI and

4. The Fate of Dr. Leichhardt and a proposed New Search of His Party
i.e., respectively B62.03.03, B65.02.09, B65.04.01 and either B65.13.05 or B6513.06 (B65.02.01 is less likely)
and most humbly hand them over to Your Royal Highness with the devoted request
His Highness might deign to graciously accept these as proof of deepest devotion from him and to allow partaking of the honour of an incorporation into the Grand ducal Library.

In what manner Dr. Frdn. Mueller as Mecklenburger represents the dear fatherland and works to its honour in a distant part of the world, the insignia,
By mid-1865 M had several decorations, including from within the German speaking areas Knights Cross Franz-Josephs Orden (Austria) and Knight Sachsen-Ernestinischer-Haus-Orden (Saxe-Coburg and Gotha) (see on this website 'Ferdinand Mueller's Honours, Awards and Memberships'); M had just been appointed to the Order of the Wendish Crown when this letter was written, see Friedrich Franz II, Grand Duke of Mecklenburg to M, 9 November 1865. with which the breast of this acknowledged scholar already is decorated and whose photographic image I most humbly dare to enclose, bear witness.
With sincerest elation I have achieved hereby this commission of my worthy fellow countryman most joyfully.
